title: 111_hr3051
content: The "Plain Language in Health Insurance Act of 2009" aims to enhance the clarity and effectiveness of communication from health insurance issuers, health plans, and Federal health care programs by promoting clear and easily understandable language in all publicly distributed documents. This Act defines "covered document" as any document issued by these entities and "plain language" as language that is clear, concise, well-organized, and follows best practices for easy comprehension. SEC. 4. RESPONSIBILITIES OF HEALTH INSURANCE ISSUERS, HEALTH PLANS, AND FEDERAL HEALTH CARE PROGRAMS. Health insurance issuers, health plans, and Federal health care programs must use plain language in new documents within 1 year of this Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide guidance on implementation within 6 months. Interim guidance will be issued before the final guidance. Health insurance issuers, health plans, and Federal health care programs must use plain language in new documents within 1 year of this Act. Interim guidance can be followed before final guidance is issued. If a violation is found, corrective action plans must be submitted within 90 days for review. Health insurance issuers and health plans must submit a corrective action plan within 90 days for review and approval by the Secretary. Civil penalties of up to $10,000 per violation and $50,000 for all violations in a single proceeding may be imposed. The Secretary will establish mechanisms to ensure Federal health care programs comply with the requirements. SEC. 5. REPORTS TO CONGRESS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment outlining plans to communicate, train employees, ensure compliance, enforce, and designate a senior official for implementing the Act's requirements. The Secretary must submit reports on compliance with the Act annually for the first 2 years after enactment, and once every 3 years thereafter to specific committees in Congress.
